24288905.review:
Better than I remember it on PS3. Before I lost my game disc, that is.

Fighting is extremely fluid. The game is easy to learn, but hard to master. Complex system mechanics and lots of meter management await for those who want to dive deep.

The cast is varied. No two characters play alike. Or look alike. No clones in this fighting game.

The game is easy on the eyes. Buttery-smooth 60FPS spritework, hand-drawn goodness. Of course, that comes with a downside. Anything above 1080p is scaled; nobody is going to re-draw complex sprite-based animations for every resolution under the sun.

Colors and effects are nice and popping, interface is pretty clean, and the game lets you know if you performed a combo that isn't a true combo - great for newbies to know what's techable and what could potentially be punished if their opponent catches on.

If this is your first fighting game, it's not a bad choice, but the games Arc System Works actually developed (not just published like this one) and Skullgirls all have very in-depth tutorials for complete fighting game newbies to learn basics that are not only useful in the game they're in, but in every fighting game. 

Finally, if you want a community, check out the discord chat. https://discord.gg/tEbWk3Z

24288889.review:
Under Night In-Birth ported to Steam?! 2 year old game (4 if you want to count arcades) that was ported to PC by ArcSys. This beautifully anime pixel artstyle fighting game made it's way across Steam/Pc for others to be played. The visuals and colorful aspects of the game would appeal anyone who enjoys good, vibrant art style along with flashy effects. The OST is the best in the fighting game genre with it's variety of character's. Different characters to choose from, different stages and modes to play through. You can enjoy various gameplay mode's such as Arcade, Survival, Time Attack, Training and Network! You can also customize your characters by puchasing colors set to your profile, as well as your online Avatar, Title plate, and title! Play in VS, Arcade, or Network to rake IP points to buy all colors! *10 additional colors for every character to purchase in the store*. 

Under Night in-Birth is my favorite fighting game, however, it is being proclaimed dead by the FGC. It my favorite fighting game, I will give it my honest review for anyone than being biased about their traits. 

Gameplay (8/10): For those who enjoy fast, chain-combo'ing fighting games, this one's for you! If you've enjoyed Blazblue or any of it's iterations, give this one a shot! Flashy vibrant colors, awesome sound effects, and an enjoyable soundtrack to go through makes this the perfect anime fighting game. Different variety of characters to choose from, all being very distinct to their character and not being copy/pasted. Modes ranging from Arcade, Time attack, Survival, and Network, you can choose to play different types for maximum playthrough. 

Netcode/Online (8/10): Having played Network as soon as the release, based off the initial Netcode, it is most like the PS3 version of  the game. Rarely any lag spikes, and smooth sailing for your combos. 

Artstyle (10/10): The game's beautiful!! For being an anime pixel game, you can expect non-boring colors while playing Under Night.

Sound/BGM (10/10): Best background music and sound effects in the game. You can expect different style music, and very fitting and distint to one character's personality. Hard to get tired of listening to any of these OST. 

Offline 1v1 (X/X): Being a port from the PS3, you can safely assume that offline is much better than online. I haven't tried this offline yet, but basing off online you can expect it to be just fine. 

Now to wait for UNI[st] C:

24288108.review:
Character sprites are well animated, soundtrack is above average.

But what makes this 2d fighter extremely satisfying to play is the fast pace combat
I though a 4 buttons fighter would be pretty simple to master... oh boy was i wrong

Combos are pretty easy to pull off if you are veteran of this type of fighter, put a couple hours into training mode and you'll be doing 10-20 hits on your opponent consistently.
The mechanic of this game is the GRD guage on the bottom of the screen, you gain this meter by walking into your opponent and hitting them; dashing back and getting hit will lose you meters. Theres a timer on this gauge, when the timer hits whoever have the higher GRD meter will gain a buff. With this buff you do 10% more damage and you can cash in this buff to gain EX meter.  You can also guard break using this buff....and a lot more mechainc that are hard for me to explain

The only problem is this game have no tutorial mode... I learned the mechanics above from watching a youtube tutorial...

The inputs only have xbox input label, kindna annoys me a little.
Online netcode is a bit iffy, but not unplayable.

24287299.review:
UNIEL is a very solid fighting game, developed by French Bread. You might be more familiar with their work on Melty Blood, and if you are then you should certainly already know the quality of the game. The roster in UNIEL is amazingly varied, with everything from your robotic lolita girl, to a creature that looks like he came straight out of EVA. Gameplay-wise, the roster is balanced as well, with the top-tiers not being as dominating as one would usually think they are in an anime fighting game.

One thing that might shy people away from the game is their previous experience with anime fighters, the overly fast pace and intense combo game in particular. While there is potential for long, execution-heavy combos, they are not mandatory to learn the game, which is going to come as a relief to many. Your bread and butter can be found online without much difficulty, and the community tends to be very welcoming towards newcomers.

With it previously having been a PS3 exclusive, the PC playerbase have previously not had access to the game. Fighting games have a terrible tendency of getting the previous iteration released on PC just when the new one is coming out, but that's not the case this time around, as the sequel titled UNIst, is still not out on console. UNIEL is the latest iteration on the franchise both on PC and console, so don't worry about making a poor business decision in that sense. 


I hope you all have as much fun with this game as I have. If there's ever any questions you might have over the game, feel free to message me and I'll be glad to help. Happy playing!
